summary: Early Christian sources often speak of baptism with regeneration/remission vocabulary; later traditions diverge on whether that implies sacramental instrumentality, covenantal sign, or a layered account of both.

key_points.text: 2nd–5th century writers commonly connect baptism with regeneration/remission language.
Medieval synthesis treats baptism as a regenerating/remitting sacrament.
Reformation debates intensify around instrumentality and timing.

summary: Baptism is the sacrament of regeneration through water and the word; it effects new birth and incorporation into Christ and the Church.

key_points.text: CCC explicitly frames baptism as regeneration/new birth.
Aquinas systematizes baptism’s regenerating effects using ‘laver of regeneration’ framing.

summary: Baptism is ordinarily understood sacramentally as new birth and entry into the life of Christ and His Church, supported by patristic theology and liturgical practice.

key_points.text: Justin’s baptismal language shows early sacramental framing of regeneration.

summary: Baptism truly delivers forgiveness and salvation because God’s Word and promise are joined to the water; its benefits are received in faith.

key_points.text: Small Catechism: baptism delivers forgiveness and salvation to those who believe the promise.
Large Catechism: baptism’s power is not mere water but Word + water.

summary: Baptism is a divine ordinance where grace is truly exhibited to those it belongs to, but its efficacy is not mechanically tied to the moment of administration.

key_points.text: Westminster: efficacy not tied to the moment; grace conferred in God’s appointed time.

summary: Baptism is primarily a covenant sign/marker of belonging rather than a regenerating instrument that itself causes new birth.

key_points.text: Britannica and Schaff summarize Zwingli’s emphasis on signs rather than means of grace.

summary: All major Christian traditions affirm the Son's co-eternity with the Father, though the precise theological language developed through centuries of controversy.

key_points.text: John's Gospel provides foundational texts identifying the Logos with God.
The Council of Nicaea definitively established homoousios as orthodox doctrine.

summary: The doctrine of one divine essence in three persons is affirmed by all major Christian traditions as central to Christian faith.

key_points.text: Tertullian first articulated the formula 'one substance, three persons.'
The Athanasian Creed provides the most detailed articulation of Trinitarian doctrine.

summary: Most Christian traditions affirm some form of Christ's real presence in the Eucharist, though they differ significantly on the mode of that presence.

key_points.text: Early church writers like Ignatius speak of the Eucharist as Christ's flesh.
Reformation debates produced three main positions: transubstantiation, sacramental union, and memorial.

summary: Christ is substantially present under the forms of bread and wine through transubstantiation, the whole Christ in each species.

key_points.text: Lateran IV and Trent define transubstantiation as the change of substance.
Aquinas provides the standard scholastic explanation using Aristotelian categories.

summary: Christ's body and blood are truly present 'in, with, and under' the bread and wine (sacramental union), received by all who eat and drink.

key_points.text: Luther rejected transubstantiation but strongly affirmed Real Presence.

summary: Christ is truly present in the Supper, but spiritually — believers are lifted to heaven by the Spirit to commune with the glorified Christ.

key_points.text: Calvin mediates between Luther and Zwingli with his doctrine of spiritual presence.

summary: The Lord's Supper is a memorial meal in which believers remember Christ's sacrifice; 'This is my body' means 'represents.'

key_points.text: Zwingli argued for a purely symbolic understanding at Marburg.
